The '''DP70''' is a model of [[Movie projector|motion picture projector]], of which approximately 1,500 were manufactured by the Electro-Acoustics Division of [[Philips]] between 1954 and about 1968.<ref>http://in70mm.com/dp70/story/index.htm</ref> It is notable for having been the first mass-produced theater projector in which [[35mm film#Academy format|4/35]] and [[70mm film|5/70]] [[Release print|prints]] could be projected by a single machine, thereby enabling wide film to become a mainstream exhibition technology, for its recognition in the [[35th Academy Awards|1963 Academy Awards]], which led to it being described as "the only projector to win an Oscar" (though this is technically incorrect, because the award was actually a Class 2 Oscar Plaque), and for its longevity: a significant number remain in revenue-earning service at the time of writing (February 2014).
==Research and development== Small-scale attempts had been made to use wide film for commercial theater exhibition around the time of the conversion to sound, of which [[70 mm Grandeur film|Fox Grandeur]] was technologically the closest to the format the DP70 was designed to facilitate the launch of, two decades later. One of the reasons these early systems failed to establish wide film as an industry standard was that the projectors developed for them were incompatible with the existing 4/35 standard. In order to be able to project both, therefore, theaters had to be equipped with two sets of projectors, which involved significant extra cost and in some cases architectural modifications to projection booths.
The DP70 (DP stands for "Double Projector") was invented and developed by a team headed by Jan-Jacob Kotte of Philips between 1952–54, as part of the [[Todd-AO]] system. A core objective of the project was to create a single machine that could project both the [[70mm film#Todd-AO|Todd-AO 5/70 format]] and the 4/35 format which was, and was likely to remain, the dominant standard for theater exhibition.
==Service history== The first DP70s were exported from The Netherlands to the United States in the fall of 1954, and were used for the [[Roadshow theatrical release|roadshow]] release of the feature that was made to launch Todd-AO, [[Oklahoma! (1955 film)|''Oklahoma!'']] DP70s were used exclusively as part of the Todd-AO system for the first few years, but were eventually sold independently by Philips and its resellers to theaters worldwide. The DP70 was widely praised for its versatility, reliability and ease of use, which was recognized by the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|Academy]] in 1963. During the 1960s DP70 installations appeared throughout the world, mainly in prestige, downtown first run venues. As a result of the machine's success, dual gauge projectors were quickly developed and launched by Philips's main competitors, notably [[Cinemeccanica]] of Italy and Century of the United States.
Almost 60 years after the first DP70s shipped from the factory, a significant number remain in regular, commercial use worldwide. In 1972 the cinema division of Philips was bought out by [[Kinoton]], a German company that had handled European sales and support for Philips cinema products since 1949.<ref name="kinoton_history">{{cite web | url=http://www.kinoton.de/en/kinoton/history.html | title=Kinoton History | work=Kinoton.de | publisher=Unknown | location=Germering, Germany | date=Unknown | accessdate=6 May 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PNtJGBsG | archivedate=6 May 2014}}</ref> After-sales support for the DP70 passed to Kinoton at that point, which continued to manufacture and distribute replacement parts until the company was wound up in April 2014.<ref name="kinoton_closed">{{cite web | url=http://celluloidjunkie.com/2014/04/01/kinoton-latest-victim-switch-digital-cinema/ | title=Kinoton is Latest Victim of Switch to Digital Cinema | work=Celluloid Junkie | publisher=Unknown | location=Unknown | date=1 April 2014 | accessdate=6 May 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PNszNWzo | archivedate=6 May 2014}}</ref> Accessories and modifications are available (some of them were made by Kinoton, others by [[Aftermarket (automotive)|aftermarket]] manufacturers) that will enable the DP70 to project every 5/70 and 4/35 format that was ever used on a significant scale, most notably for the 35mm digital optical sound systems launched in the 1990s, e.g. [[Dolby Digital#Dolby Digital in the cinema|Dolby Digital]], and for [[DTS (sound system)#DTS 70 mm|70mm DTS]].
Though the projection of film itself in mainstream, first run theaters has been superseded almost completely by [[Digital cinema|digital projection]] at the time of writing, DP70s remain in service in [[cinematheque]]-type venues that specialize in showing [[Art film|repertory]] and [[Film preservation|archive]] titles. Theaters in which DP70s are still running today include the [[Grauman's Egyptian Theatre|Egyptian Theatre]] in [[Hollywood]], the [[Gartenbaukino]] in Vienna, the Pictureville cinema at the UK's [[National Media Museum]] and [[:sv:Rigoletto (biograf)|Rigoletto]] in Stockholm.
==Nomenclature== The fact that the DP70 was a Dutch machine developed specifically for a customer in the United States resulted in it being known by several different names. The DP70 was Philips's original model name for the projector, and this is what projectionists in Europe tend to call it. In the United States, the [[American Optical Company]] (the AO in Todd-AO) used the Philips factory model number, EL4000/01 (the 60 Hz variant - the 50 Hz one, for sale in European markets, was model no. EL4000/00), as their catalog number for the machine. It was eventually marketed independently of Todd-AO by [[Norelco]] (a contraction of "North American Philips Electrical Company", i.e. the brand name used by Philips in the US).<ref name="DP70_brochure">{{cite web | url=http://in70mm.com/dp70/library/brochures/pdf/Universal_70_35_Projector.pdf | title=Norelco Universal 70-35 Projector | work=in70mm.com | publisher=Norelco | location=Buffalo, New York | date=1955 | accessdate=6 May 2014 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PNtlxlJR | archivedate=6 May 2014}}</ref> The DP70 was originally sold in the United States simply as the "Norelco Universal 70/35mm Motion Picture Projector". After its acknowledgment in the 1963 Oscars, Norelco rebranded it as the AA (Academy Award). An improved version of the projector was also launched in 1963, which was branded as the AAII in the US.
All the projector mechanisms were built at the Philips factory in [[Eindhoven]], though much of the peripheral hardware for the machines that were exported to the United States, e.g. bases and reel magazines, was manufactured locally, initially by the American Optical Company and later by [[Ballantyne Strong, Inc.|Ballantyne]].
==Features==
===Overview=== The DP70 consists of a [[monocoque]], cast iron chassis containing the mechanism, which is completely oil-immersed on the non-operating side. Jan-Jacob Kotte believed that the use of heavier materials to absorb vibration reduced instability in the projected image, and this is certainly reflected in the design of the DP70: a complete outfit, including the bases and reel magazines, weighs 1,004 lbs - literally half a ton! The DP70 was also significantly more expensive than any single gauge theater projector on the market: a US customer was quoted $6,225 for one in 1966 ($44,942 in 2014, adjusted for [[Consumer price index|CPI]] inflation), which was around the cost of a typical three-bedroom suburban home at the time.<ref>http://www.in70mm.com/dp70/story/index.htm</ref> The price asked for a double set without lenses asked in West-Germany in 1956 was 42,510.00 Marks, which at the rate of exchange at that time (4:1), related to 10,627.50 $ for the pair, or 5,313.75 $ per projector.<ref>invoice from 1956-12</ref> That price was higher, than 35mm only projectors, but still reasonably low if compared to competitors like Bauer U2.<ref>Invoice from 1959-09</ref> The low price and reasonable quality was an important part of the success. Because the DP70 was built to commission for a customer in the United States, it is a very unusual example of a European-designed piece of industrial machinery with [[fastener]]s that have [[SAE International|SAE]] rather than [[Metric system|metric]] dimensions.
===Removable components===
Detachable reel magazines can be fitted (e.g. to enable the projection of [[Nitrocellulose#Nitrate film|nitrate film]] in accordance with safety regulations), or removed (e.g. to enable projection using an external film transport device such as a platter or tower, or to fit an external audio reader) as needed. Special fire trap rollers for nitrate were also available, to comply with fire regulations in some jurisdictions. Separate [[Movie projector#Magnetic sound|magnetic]] and [[Movie projector#Analog Optical Sound|analog optical]] audio heads are built into the mechanism itself, enabling all 5/70 magnetic and 4/35 optical formats to be projected without the need to adjust or replace any audio components. The change of gauge is done by swapping some gate components, pad roller assemblies, reel spindles and the lens, and in some cases making minor adjustments to the lamphouse. This procedure can be completed by a competent [[projectionist]] in 5–10 minutes, which is a major reason for the DP70's popularity with venues that show 4/35 and 5/70 prints interchangeably.
===Cooling===
Because the DP70 was intended for use with 70mm film and in large theaters with a long throw to a big screen, several features were included to disperse the intense heat generated by the more powerful lamps with which it was often used. The gate assembly includes [[copper]] components which are silver-plated, and a liquid-cooled plate that is fitted with a water pipe surrounding the aperture opening. The use of liquid recirculating equipment and [[distilled water]] was encouraged. A single-blade shutter designed to rotate at very high speed (up to 3,600 [[Revolutions per minute|RPM]]) doubles as a cooling fan. Unlike other projectors of its hi-power kind, the DP 70 did not offer forced-air cooling of the film itself, which is known to be a key feature to prevent overheating of the film and the major nitrate-fire prevention measure. A water cooled pre-shield just assists in keeping the gate and metal parts cold, not the film.<ref>Bauer Kino Technisches Taschenbuch</ref>
===Motor===
The DP70 as shipped from the factory was equipped for dual speed operation, at 24[[Frame rate|fps]] (the frame rate at which almost all 4/35 prints with a combined soundtrack are projected at) and 30fps, the frame rate used in the original Todd-AO system. The original version of the DP70 used separate drive motors for 24fps and 30fps operation, whereas the AAII had a single motor and a dual locking pulley mechanism on the main drive shaft to change the speed of the mechanism. There were also several other more minor changes in the AAII.
Because many of the DP70s remaining in use today are in repertory venues that screen a wide range of formats, including prints of [[Silent film#Projection speeds|silent movies]] that require a lower frame rate than 24, a lot of them have now received aftermarket modifications that will typically enable any speed between 16 and 30. Since US market DP70 seem to be factory equipped with synchronous motors that lock their speed (1,800 RPM in the USA) to the [[Alternating current|AC]] line frequency (60 [[Hertz|Hz]] in the USA), the most common way of doing this has been to add a variable frequency solid state AC [[Power inverter|inverter]] (Baldor Inverter) to drive the 24fps motor. Most European units were sold employing asynchronous motors, which added slip to the synchronous speed (1500 RPM at 50 Hz) to achieve the required 24 frames (1440 RPM) and 30 frames (1800 rpm), without gearing requirements in the original construction.

A '''polymer-bonded explosive''', also called '''PBX''' or '''plastic-bonded explosive''', is an [[explosive]] material in which explosive powder is bound together in a matrix using small quantities (typically 5–10% by weight) of a synthetic [[polymer]]. PBXs are normally used for explosive materials that are not easily melted into a casting, or are otherwise difficult to form. PBX was first developed in 1952 in [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]], as [[RDX]] embedded in [[polystyrene]] with [[dioctyl phthalate]] [[plasticizer]]. [[HMX]] compositions with [[teflon]]-based binders were developed in 1960s and 1970s for [[shell (projectile)|gun shells]] and for [[Apollo Lunar Surface Experiments Package]] (ALSEP) seismic experiments,<ref name="chemexpl" /> although the latter experiments are usually cited as using [[hexanitrostilbene]] (HNS).<ref name=nasa-alsep>{{cite web |url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/lunar/documents/NASA%20RP-1036.pdf |title=ALSEP (Apollo Lunar Surface Experiments Package) Termination Report |authors=James R.Bates; W.W.Lauderdale; Harold Kernaghan |date=April 1979 |format=pdf-8.81 mb |publisher=NASA-Scientific and Technical Information Office |accessdate=2014-06-29}}</ref>
== Potential advantages == Polymer-bonded explosives have several potential advantages: * If the polymer matrix is an [[elastomer]] (rubbery material), it tends to absorb shocks, making the PBX very insensitive to accidental detonation, and thus ideal for [[insensitive munitions]]. * Hard polymers can produce PBX that is very rigid and maintains a precise engineering shape even under severe stress. * PBX powders can be pressed into a particular shape at room temperature, when casting normally requires hazardous melting of the explosive. High pressure pressing can achieve density for the material very close to the theoretical crystal density of the base explosive material. * Many PBXes are safe to machine—to turn solid blocks into complex three-dimensional shapes. For example, a [[billet (manufacturing)|billet]] of PBX can, if necessary, be precisely shaped on a [[lathe]] or [[CNC machine]]. This technique is used to machine [[explosive lens]]es necessary for modern nuclear weapons.<ref name=nuke-arch-explo>{{cite web |url=http://nuclearweaponarchive.org/Nwfaq/Nfaq4-1.html#4.1.6.2.2.5 |author=Carey Sublette |work=4. Engineering and Design of Nuclear Weapons: 4.1 Elements of Fission Weapon Design |title=4.1.6.2.2.5 Explosives |date=1999-02-20 |publisher=nuclearweaponarchive.org |accessdate=2010-02-08}}</ref>
== Binders ==
=== Fluoropolymers === [[Fluoropolymer]]s are advantageous as binders due to their high [[density]] (yielding high [[detonation velocity]]) and inert chemical behavior (yielding long shelf stability and low [[Aging (material science)|aging]]). They are however somewhat brittle, as their [[glass transition]] temperature is at room temperature or above; this limits their use to insensitive explosives (e.g. [[TATB]]) where the brittleness does not have detrimental effect to safety. They are also difficult to process.<ref name="nonshockinit" />
=== Elastomers === [[Elastomer]]s have to be used with more mechanically sensitive explosives, e.g. [[HMX]]. The elasticity of the matrix lowers sensitivity of the bulk material to shock and friction; their glass transition temperature is chosen to be below the lower boundary of the temperature working range (typically below -55 °C). [[Crosslinked]] [[synthetic rubber|rubber]] polymers are however sensitive to aging, mostly by action of [[free radical]]s and by [[hydrolysis]] of the bonds by traces of water vapor. Rubbers like [[thermoplastic polyurethanes|Estane]] or [[hydroxyl-terminated polybutadiene]] (HTPB) are used for these applications extensively. [[Silicone rubber]]s and [[thermoplastic polyurethanes]] are also in use.<ref name="nonshockinit" />
[[Fluoroelastomer]]s, e.g. [[Viton]], combine the advantages of both.
=== Energetic polymers === Energetic polymers (e.g. nitro or azido derivates of polymers) can be used as a binder to increase the explosive power in comparison with inert binders. [[Plasticizer#Plasticizers for energetic materials|Energetic plasticizers]] can be also used. The addition of a plasticizer lowers the sensitivity of the explosive and improves its processibility.<ref name="chemexpl">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9tIQDn2uZz4C&pg=PA11&dq=polymer+bonded+explosives&cd=1#v=onepage&q=polymer%20bonded%20explosives&f=false |title=The Chemistry of Explosives |edition=2nd |isbn=978-0-85404-640-9 |author1=Akhavan |first1=Jacqueline |date=2004-01-01}}</ref>
== Insults (potential explosive inhibitors) == Explosive yields can be affected by the introduction of mechanical loads or the application of temperature; such damages are called '''insults'''. The mechanism of a thermal insult at low temperatures on an explosive is primarily thermomechanical, at higher temperatures it is primarily thermochemical.
=== Thermomechanical === Thermomechanical mechanisms involve stresses by thermal expansion (namely differential thermal expansions, as thermal gradients tend to be involved), melting/freezing or sublimation/condensation of components, and phase transitions of crystals (e.g. transition of HMX from beta phase to delta phase at 175 °C involves a large change in volume and causes extensive cracking of its crystals).
=== Thermochemical === Thermochemical changes involve decomposition of the explosives and binders, loss of strength of binder as it softens or melts, or stiffening of the binder if the increased temperature causes crosslinking of the polymer chains. The changes can also significantly alter the porosity of the material, whether by increasing it (fracturing of crystals, vaporization of components) or decreasing it (melting of components). The size distribution of the crystals can be also altered, e.g. by [[Ostwald ripening]]. Thermochemical decomposition starts to occur at the crystal nonhomogeneities, e.g. intragranular interfaces between crystal growth zones, on damaged parts of the crystals, or on interfaces of different materials (e.g. crystal/binder). Presence of defects in crystals (cracks, voids, solvent inclusions...) may increase the explosive's sensitivity to mechanical shocks.<ref name="nonshockinit" />

Jenkins]] | location_city = [[Lakeland, Florida]], U.S. | num_locations = 1,242 | area_served = {{flat list| * [[Alabama]] (73) * [[Florida]] (817) * [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] (189) * [[North Carolina|North Carolina]] (42) * [[South Carolina|South Carolina]] (61) * [[Tennessee]] (45) * [[Virginia]] (15) }} | key_people = {{ublist |Todd Jones ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]){{cite web|title=Publix CEO Announces Retirement Plans; New CEO Named|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-ceo-announces-retirement-plans|publisher=Publix|accessdate=May 10, 2016}} |Ed Crenshaw ([[Chairman]])}} | brands = {{hlist|Aprons|GreenWise (products)|GreenWise Market (stores)|PIX|''Presto!''|Publix Sabor}} | services = {{Unbulleted list|[[Event planning]]|[[Money services business|Money services]]|[[Online grocer|Online shopping and home delivery]]{{wbr}} {{nobr|(via [[Instacart]])}}|[[Real estate]]{{cite web | title = Publix Real Estate | url = http://ww2.publix.com/realestate/Home.do | accessdate = March 13, 2017 }}}} | revenue = {{Unbulleted list|{{increase}} $34.56{{nbsp}}billion (2017){{cite web| title=United States Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-K Annual Report| accessdate=March 7, 2018| publisher=SEC.gov| url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/81061/000008106118000006/publix-10kx12302017.htm}}|{{increase}} $34.00{{nbsp}}billion (2016)}} | operating_income = {{Unbulleted list|{{Increase}} $3.028{{nbsp}}billion (2017)|{{Increase}} $2.940{{nbsp}}billion (2016)}} | net_income = {{Unbulleted list|{{increase}} $2.292{{nbsp}}billion (2017)|{{increase}} $2.026{{nbsp}}billion (2016)}} | assets = {{Unbulleted list|{{Increase}} $18.18{{nbsp}}billion (2017)|{{Increase}} $17.39{{nbsp}}billion (2016)}} | equity = {{Unbulleted list|{{Increase}} $14.11{{nbsp}}billion (2017)|{{Increase}} $13.50{{nbsp}}billion (2016)}} | num_employees = 193,000 | num_employees_year = 2018 | homepage = {{URL|https://www.publix.com}} }} '''Publix Super Markets, Inc.''', commonly known as '''Publix''', is an [[employee ownership|employee-owned]], [[United States|American]] [[supermarket]] chain headquartered in [[Lakeland, Florida|Lakeland]], [[Florida]].{{Cite web|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/company-overview/facts-figures|title=Facts & Figures|last=|first=|date=|website=Publix Super Markets|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} Founded in 1930 by [[George W. Jenkins]], Publix is a [[Privately held company|private corporation]] that is wholly owned by present and past employees and members of the Jenkins family. {{Cite web|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/company-overview|title=About Publix|last=|first=|date=|website=Publix.com|accessdate=July 28, 2017}} Publix operates throughout the [[Southeastern United States]], with locations in [[Florida]] (817), [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] (189), [[Alabama]] (73), [[South Carolina]] (61), [[Tennessee]] (45), [[North Carolina]] (42), and [[Virginia]] (15). Publix stands as one of the largest U.S. regional grocery chains. Locations are found as far north as [[Spotsylvania, Virginia]], as far south as [[Key West, Florida]], while the westernmost location is in [[Mobile, Alabama]]. Today, the state of [[Florida]] still has the largest number of stores, with 787, about two-thirds of the outlets. As of August 2018, Publix employs about 193,000 people at its 1,231 retail locations, cooking schools, corporate offices, 9 grocery [[Warehouse|distribution centers]], and 11 manufacturing facilities. The manufacturing facilities produce its [[dairy]], [[Delicatessen|deli]], [[bakery]], and other food products. Publix is ranked No. 47 on [[Fortune (magazine)|''Fortune'']] magazine's list of 100 Best Companies to Work For 2018, down from No. 21 in 2017,{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/best-companies/publix-super-markets/|title=100 Best Companies to Work For|newspaper=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|accessdate=June 2, 2018}} and was ranked No. 7 on ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}} 2017 list of America's Largest Private Companies and is the largest in Florida.{{cite news| title=America's Largest Private Companies| url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/publix-super-markets/| magazine=Forbes| accessdate=September 7, 2015}} ''Fortune'' ranked Publix #1 on their 2018 list of World's Most Admired Companies in the Food & Drug Stores sector.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/best-companies/publix-super-markets/|title=World's Most Admired Companies - Food & Drug Stores|magazine=Forbes|accessdate=January 22, 2018}} The company's 2017 sales totaled [[United States dollar|US$]]34.6 billion, with profits of $2.3 billion, ranking No. 88 on ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine's [[Fortune 500]] list of U.S. companies by revenue for 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/publix-super-markets/|title=Fortune Magazine|year=2016|website=Fortune 500|accessdate=June 2, 2018}} According to the [[National Retail Federation]], based on 2016 revenue, Publix is the fifteenth-largest U.S. [[retailer]].{{cite news| url=https://stores.org/stores-top-retailers-2017/| title=2017 Top 100 Retailers| work=''Stores'' | year=2017|accessdate=June 2, 2018}}{{better source|reason=NRF is not independent. List does not include Amazon, etc.|date=June 2018}} Publix stock is only available for purchase by eligible active employees and non-employee members of its [[Board of directors|Board of Directors]]. == History == ===Early history=== [[Image:FirstPublix.jpg|thumb|The first Publix Super Market in [[Winter Haven, Florida]], circa 1940. It is now a [[thrift store]].{{cite news|last=Rowe|first=Trent|title=The Insider: St. Matt's Is Moving|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20091218/news/912185032#gsc.tab=0|accessdate= February 5, 2014|newspaper=[[The Ledger]]|location=[[Lakeland, Florida]]|date=December 18, 2009}}]] [[George W. Jenkins|George Jenkins]] opened the first Publix market in [[Winter Haven, Florida]], on September 6, 1930 - a 27 ft by 65 ft building at 199 West Central Avenue.{{cite web| title=History| url=http://www.publix.com/about/PublixHistory.do| publisher=Publix| accessdate=October 10, 2011}}{{cite web|publisher=Publix|url=https://twitter.com/Publix/status/430854647038091265|title=@aheneen The first store was located at 199 West Central Avenue. :) ^CO|work=Twitter|accessdate=November 11, 2015}} In 1934, that store made $120,000 in sales. In 1935, he opened a second market, the Economy Food Store, also in Winter Haven. Despite the [[Great Depression]], his stores were financially successful. In 1940, Jenkins, affectionately called "Mr. George" by his employees, [[Mortgage loan|mortgaged]] an [[Orange (fruit)|orange]] grove to build Florida's first [[supermarket]]. His "food palace" had [[Elevator music|piped-in music]], [[air conditioning]], cold cases for [[Frozen food|frozen]] and [[refrigerated]] items, in-store [[doughnut]] and [[Floristry|flower shops]], and [[Electric eye|electric-eye automatic doors]]. During [[World War II]], material shortages prevented him from building additional stores. In 1945, Jenkins purchased the 19-store All American chain of food stores and converted them into Publix Super Markets. In 1951, Publix moved its headquarters from [[Winter Haven, Florida|Winter Haven]] to [[Lakeland, Florida]], and built its first distribution [[warehouse]] there. At the same time, they began to close the All American stores, replacing them with Publix markets. In 1956, Publix achieved $50 million in sales, and $1 million in profit. In 1957, the donut shop in each store was expanded into a full-service bakery.{{fact|date=May 2018}} ===Florida expansion=== [[File:PublixMiamiBeach.JPG|thumb|A 1960s-style Publix Super Market store [[Marquee (sign)|marquee]] on Dade Avenue in [[Miami Beach, Florida]]]] By 1959, Publix was the dominant supermarket chain in [[Central Florida]], and began expansion to [[South Florida]]. In 1963, the company built a distribution center in [[Miami]], and began providing [[Delicatessen|deli]] services. In 1970, sales surpassed $500 million; they reached $1 billion in 1974, when the chain expanded to include [[Jacksonville, Florida]].{{cn|date=May 2018}} In 1982, the company launched the ''[[#Presto!|Presto!]]'' [[automated teller machine|ATM]] network; it soon installed ATMs in every Publix. Sales exceeded $5 billion in 1989.{{cite web| title=Photo Timeline| publisher=Publix| url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/culture/history/photo-timeline | accessdate=November 8, 2015}} In 1983, [[Carol Jenkins Barnett]] joined the Publix Board of Directors and served in that role until 2016. During her time at Publix, the company grew into the largest supermarket chain in Florida, expanded into five other states, and recorded $32.5 billion in sales in 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/consumer/os-publix-carol-jenkins-barnett-alzheimers-20160617-story.html|title=Publix director Carol Jenkins Barnett, daughter of founder, steps down at 59 with Alzheimer's diagnosis|last=Arnold|first=Kyle|work=OrlandoSentinel.com|accessdate=November 28, 2017|language=en-US}} [[File:Publix Britton Plaza 2008 1.jpg|thumb|A converted Albertsons location in [[South Tampa|South Tampa, Florida]]]] Publix Super Markets bought 49 Florida stores from [[Albertsons LLC|Albertsons]]. The deal was announced on June 9, 2008, and was completed on September 9, 2008. It included 15 locations in [[North Florida]], 30 in [[Central Florida]], and four in [[South Florida]]. The sale allowed Publix to operate four stores in a new market area for the company, [[Escambia County, Florida]] (the [[Pensacola]] area).{{Cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-06-10/business/publix10_1_albertsons-stores-publix-grocery|title=Publix to buy 49 Albertsons stores in Florida|work=tribunedigital-orlandosentinel|accessdate=November 28, 2017|language=en}} On February 5, 2009, Publix opened its 1,000th store in [[St. Augustine, Florida]], allowing the company to become one of only five U.S. grocery retailers to operate that many stores. The St. Augustine store is among Publix's first stores designed to be [[efficient energy use|energy-efficient]]. The store includes [[motion sensor]] lights throughout the store, including on the freezer doors, and an overhead light system that can be controlled by each department.{{cite news| title=Publix Ready to Open Its 1,000th Store Next Month In St. Augustine| url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20090121/NEWS/901210361?Title=Publix-Ready-to-Open-Its-1-000th-Store-Next-Month-In-St-Augustine&tc=ar| date=January 21, 2009| author=Kyle Kennedy| work=The Ledger|location=Lakeland, Florida| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} ===Southern and Mid-Atlantic expansion=== The first Publix outside [[Florida]] opened in [[Savannah, Georgia]], in 1991; distribution and manufacturing facilities in [[Dacula, Georgia]] (a northeastern suburb of [[Atlanta]]) soon followed, as it began to expand into [[Atlanta metropolitan area|metro Atlanta]] in 1993. Publix further expanded into [[South Carolina]] (1993), [[Alabama]] (1996), [[Tennessee]] (2002), [[North Carolina]] (2014) and [[Virginia]] (2017). In 2011, Publix announced it was expanding into [[North Carolina]], initially by opening stores in the [[Charlotte metropolitan area]],{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/print-edition/2011/04/08/Publix-lines-up-second-site-in-region.html?s=print |title=Publix lines up second site in Charlotte region; two more in works - Charlotte Business Journal |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date=April 8, 2011 |accessdate=October 23, 2013}} and later announced construction of a new store in [[Asheville, North Carolina|Asheville]].{{cite news|url=http://www.wlos.com/template/cgi-bin/archived.pl?type=basic&file=/shared/news/features/top-stories/stories/archive/2013/08/JmecSVL8.xml#.UkbW3j_Nl0k |title=Search Results - WLOS ABC13 |publisher=WLOS |date= |accessdate=October 23, 2013}} The first Charlotte-area Publix stores (on the [[South Carolina]] [[Fort Mill, South Carolina|side of the metropolitan area]], opened in 2012); the first [[North Carolina]] Publix store opened in [[Ballantyne, North Carolina|Ballantyne]] in 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2014/02/25/4723568/publix-set-to-open-wednesday-in.html# |title=Publix opens in Ballantyne; first store in North Carolina |publisher=Charlotte Observer |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2014}} Concurrently, Publix purchased seven Charlotte-area locations from competitor [[BI-LO (United States)|BI-LO]] stores.{{Cite web|title = Publix to buy seven Bi-Lo stores in Charlotte area - Charlotte Business Journal|url = http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/blog/going_green/2013/09/publix-to-buy-seven-bi-lo-stores-in.html|website = Charlotte Business Journal|accessdate = November 5, 2015}} Publix completed the purchase of property in [[Boone, North Carolina]] on November 20, 2015 with plans to open in 2017.{{cite web | url=http://www.wataugademocrat.com/news/kmart-site-sold-to-publix-for-m/article_40c0342d-30ec-5777-849b-6f42d2cc1eed.html | title=Kmart Site Sold to Publix | date=November 23, 2015 | accessdate=November 23, 2015}} In February 2016, Publix announced their entry into the [[Virginia]] market, with the signing of two store leases, the first in [[Bristol, Virginia|Bristol]] scheduled to open in 2017 and the second in [[metropolitan area|metropolitan]] [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] scheduled for 2018.{{Cite web|title = Publix supermarkets are coming to Virginia - The Roanoke Times|url = http://www.roanoke.com/business/columns_and_blogs/blogs/storefront/publix-supermarkets-are-coming-to-virginia/article_c8025245-42ee-5a61-81aa-dd292f33c419.html|website = The Roanoke Times|accessdate = February 6, 2016}} In July 2016, it was announced that Publix had entered into a purchase agreement with [[Ahold]] and [[Delhaize Group]] for 10 [[Giant-Carlisle#Martin's|Martin's Food Markets]] locations in the Richmond market as part of the divestiture of stores to gain clearance from the [[Federal Trade Commission]] for the impending Ahold/Delhaize merger. [[Image:Publix Pompano Beach 800px.jpg|thumb|Standalone Publix in [[Pompano Beach, Florida]], with typical architecture of early 21st-century stores]] In April 2016, Ed Crenshaw, grandson of founder George Jenkins, retired from his position as CEO.{{Cite web|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/consumer/os-publix-new-ceo-20160113-story.html|title=Publix names new CEO with Central Florida roots|last=Sentinel|first=Orlando|website=OrlandoSentinel.com|access-date=May 13, 2016}} President Todd Jones, a 36-year Publix veteran whose first job was as a Front Service Clerk (bagger), has taken on Ed's responsibilities as CEO, marking the first time that someone outside the Jenkins family is in charge of the company.{{Cite web|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/os-publix-ceo-todd-jones-20160121-story.html|title=How Publix store clerk Todd Jones rose to CEO's office|last=Sentinel|first=Orlando|website=OrlandoSentinel.com|access-date=May 13, 2016}} Ed Crenshaw will remain with Publix as Chairman of the Board of Directors.{{Cite web|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-ceo-announces-retirement-plans|title=Publix CEO Announces Retirement Plans {{!}} Newsroom|website=Publix Super Markets|access-date=May 13, 2016}} == Market == [[File:Publix Supermarket Carolina Forest.jpg|thumb|Exterior of Publix in [[Carolina Forest, South Carolina]], which opened in 2016]] Each store provides products and services in its [[grocery]], [[Delicatessen|deli]], [[bakery]], [[produce]], [[floral]], [[meat]], and [[seafood]] departments. Some stores have [[valet parking]], [[Cafeterias|cafés]], [[sushi]] bars, [[pharmacy]] departments, and/or a [[liquor store]]. The customer service counter also provides [[cheque|check]] cashing, [[money order]]s, [[Western Union]] services, [[Carpet cleaning|Rug Doctor]] rentals, and [[lottery]] tickets. Some stores also provide DVD rental services. In December 2005, Publix discontinued its photo processing service, replacing it with an online or mail-order service via the [[Snapfish]] program.{{cite news| title=HP Snapfish powers Publix Online Photo Service| author=Mark Peters| date=December 12, 2005| url=http://www.letsgodigital.org/en/news/articles/story_5389.html| publisher=Letsgodigital.org| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} The Snapfish agreement has since been terminated, and Publix no longer offers photo services. === Aprons === Publix operates 11 cooking schools under the Aprons name.{{cite web| title=Publix Aprons Cooking School| url=http://www.publix.com/recipes-planning/aprons-cooking-schools| publisher=Publix| accessdate=September 7, 2015}} The schools offer cooking demonstrations in which customers are encouraged to sample easy-to-make, nutritious dishes prepared at in-store kiosks and take a recipe card with them. All recipes are developed in-house, using easy-to-prepare or prepackaged ingredients, often available at the Aprons kiosk.{{cite news| title=Publix offers meal preparation program| work=Jacksonville Business Journal| publisher=Bizjournals.com| date=October 31, 2007}} In 2005 Publix introduced its Aprons make-ahead meals concept. Customers could purchase meals that they could assemble in-store or, for an extra charge, an Aprons associate would prepare and assemble the meals. These were standalone stores located in Jacksonville and [[Lithia, Florida]]. In summer 2009, Publix closed both locations citing lack of customer interest.{{Cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/retail/publix-ends-its-aprons-make-ahead-meals-store-experiment/1028785|title=Publix ends its Apron's Make-Ahead Meals store experiment|last=Albright|first=Mark|date=August 18, 2009|work=Tampa Bay Times|access-date=October 19, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000840/http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/retail/publix-ends-its-aprons-make-ahead-meals-store-experiment/1028785|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=}} === GreenWise Market === [[Image:Publix GreenWise Market (Tampa, FL).JPG|thumb|The exterior of a first-generation Publix GreenWise Market in [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]]]] GreenWise Market is a concept the company introduced in response to the increase in the number and [[Profit (economics)|profitability]] of [[health food store]]s. GreenWise Markets were created to increase awareness of [[nutrition]]; it focuses on organic and natural items. These stores are similar to the [[Whole Foods Market]] chain. In addition to organic and traditional products, GreenWise Markets include [[salad bar|salad]] and hot bars. The first six stores were set to be in [[Palm Beach Gardens, Florida|Palm Beach Gardens]], [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]], [[Vero Beach, Florida|Vero Beach]], [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], [[Naples, Florida|Naples]], and [[Coral Springs, Florida|Coral Springs]], Florida.{{cite news| title=Publix expands GreenWise Markets| |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/stories/2007/02/05/daily31.html| work=South Florida Business Journal| publisher=Bizjournals.com| date=February 7, 2007| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} The first GreenWise Market opened on September 27, 2007 in [[Palm Beach Gardens, Florida|Palm Beach Gardens]].{{cite press release| title=Publix GreenWise Market Debuting in Palm Beach Gardens| url=http://www.publix.com/pages/Page35.do| publisher=Publix| date=September 27, 2007| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} The second Publix GreenWise Market opened in [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]] on May 29, 2008, located in Boca Village Square.{{cite news| title=GreenWise opens in Boca with popular elements of first store| author=Jan Norris| url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/food/content/food_dining/epaper/2008/06/05/a5fn_tabletalk_0605.html| work=Palm Beach Post| date=June 5, 2008| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} The third Publix GreenWise Market opened November 6, 2008, in Tampa's [[Hyde Park, Tampa, Florida|Hyde Park]] neighborhood.{{cite news| title=Publix GreenWise Market Is No Traditional Store| url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20081104/NEWS/811040363?tc=ar| author=Mark Albright| newspaper=The Ledger|location=Lakeland, Florida|date=November 4, 2008| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} [[Image:Publix GreenWise Market (Tampa, FL) Interior.JPG|thumb|The interior of a first-generation Publix GreenWise Market]] From 2008 to 2016, the company focused on a "hybrid" concept instead,{{Cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/consumer/os-bz-publix-greenwise-20170331-story.html|title=Publix putting GreenWise stores back in plans|last=Arnold|first=Kyle|date=March 31, 2017|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|access-date=April 19, 2017|publisher=tronc, inc.}} integrating the GreenWise concept into traditional Publix stores. Approximately half of locations built since 2008 are considered hybrid stores. In 2017, the company announced they would resume building standalone GreenWise locations, the first of which will be near the campus of [[Florida State University]] in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]], opening in 2018. ===Publix Sabor=== Publix operates seven stores, branded "Publix Sabor" (''sabor'' is [[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "flavor"), which cater to [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic Americans]] living in Florida and offer products for Hispanics. Located in [[Miami-Dade County]] in [[Greater Miami]], the seven themed stores are spread between [[Miami]] and [[Hialeah, Florida|Hialeah]]. They have since been closed and replaced by newly built locations or merged with existing stores that are not part of the Sabor sub-brand.{{Cite web|url=http://www.publix.com/pages/publix-sabor|title=Publix Sabor|last=|first=|date=July 5, 2016|publisher=Publix Asset Management Company|access-date=July 5, 2016}} Two other Publix Sabor locations in Kissimmee and Lake Worth{{Cite news|url=http://protectingyourpocket.blog.palmbeachpost.com/2014/11/06/publix-sabor-in-lake-worth-to-close/|title=Palm Beach Post|last=|first=|date=November 6, 2014|work=Palm Beach Post blog|access-date=July 5, 2016|via=}}Galarza, Carlos. "[http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/stories/2006/04/17/story7.html?page=all Publix Sabor doesn't scare off local competition]." ''[[Orlando Business Journal]]''. Monday April 17, 2006. Retrieved on February 1, 2012. Publix Sabor locations have [[Multilingualism|bilingual]] English-Spanish employees, open seating cafés, and a wider selection of prepared foods from the deli and bakery catering to Hispanic flavors. Publix offers cafés and hot foods because many Hispanic Americans grew up in foreign cities which had open public squares where people socialize and eat. [[File:PublixPharmacy.jpg|alt=Logo of Publix Pharmacy. "Publix Pharmacy. Feeling Well. Living Better."|thumb|Logo of Publix Pharmacy]] ===Pharmacy=== The first Publix in-store [[pharmacy]] was opened on October 30, 1986, in [[Altamonte Springs, Florida]].{{Cite web|title = Publix on Twitter|url = https://twitter.com/Publix/status/660109024050876416|website = Twitter|accessdate = December 17, 2015}} By 1995, one-third of Publix stores had a pharmacy and today, approximately 90% of Publix stores include a pharmacy. Publix Pharmacies consistently ranked number one for customer satisfaction in supermarket pharmacies in several surveys conducted by independent research companies.{{Cite news|url=http://www.drugstorenews.com/article/publix-earns-top-spot-consumer-satisfaction-survey|title=Publix earns top spot in consumer satisfaction survey|last=|first=|date=February 17, 2010|work=DrugStoreNews.com|access-date=November 28, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.jdpower.com/press-releases/jd-power-2016-us-pharmacy-study|title=J.D. Power 2016 U.S. Pharmacy Study|last=|first=|date=August 26, 2016|work=J.D. Power|access-date=November 28, 2017|language=en}} ====Free medications==== Publix announced in August 2007, that it would offer several types of [[antibiotic]]s free to its customers. Customers must have a prescription; they are given a maximum of a two-week supply.{{cite press release| title=Publix Pharmacies Launch Free Prescription Drug Program in All Operating Areas| url=http://www.publix.com/about/newsroom/NewsReleaseItem.do?newsReleaseItemPK=2636| publisher=Publix| date=August 6, 2007| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} Several medical professionals expressed concerns that this could contribute to an [[overuse of antibiotics]] which leads to [[antibiotic resistance]], a serious public health concern.{{cite news| title=Grocer Publix to Offer 7 Antibiotics for Free| author=Susan Donaldson James| url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=3456140&page=1| work=ABC News| date=August 7, 2007| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} These medications include: * [[Amoxicillin]] (excluding [[Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid]]) * [[Ampicillin]] * [[Ciprofloxacin]] (excluding Ciprofloxacin XR) * [[Penicillin VK]] and * [[Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim]] (SMZ-TMP) These antibiotics are offered to customers regardless of their prescription insurance provider. [[Doxycycline|Doxycycline Hyclate]] was removed from the list because of cost increases.{{cite web| title=Free Medications| url=http://www.publix.com/pharmacy/Free-Antibiotics.do| publisher=Publix| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} In May 2014, [[Cefalexin|Cephalexin]] was removed from the list due to cost increases.{{cite web|url=http://www.publix.com/pharmacy/Free-Medications.do|title=Welcome to Publix - Publix Super Markets|work=Publix Super Markets|accessdate=March 27, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115130134/http://www.publix.com/pharmacy/Free-Medications.do|archivedate=January 15, 2014}} In March 2010, Publix announced the launch of another free prescription, [[Metformin]] for [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|Type II Diabetes]], the generic of [[Glucophage]]. Publix provides the medication in 500 mg, 850 mg, and 1000 mg strengths. The only restriction is a 90-day supply or up to 360 500-mg, 270 850-mg, or 225 1000-mg tablets, but refills are not limited.{{cite press release| title=Publix Pharmacies Launch Free Metformin for Type II Diabetes Patients As New Diabetes Program Debuts| date= March 15, 2010| publisher=Publix| url=http://www.publix.com/about/newsroom/NewsReleaseItem.do?newsReleaseItemPK=4195| accessdate=October 19, 2011}}{{Cite web|title = Publix Pharmacy Enhances Free Medication Programs {{!}} Newsroom|url = http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-pharmacy-enhances-free-medication-programs|website = Publix Super Markets|accessdate = December 17, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207122450/http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-pharmacy-enhances-free-medication-programs|archivedate=February 7, 2018}} In August 2011, Publix began offering [[Lisinopril]], an [[ACE inhibitor]] that is used to prevent, treat, or improve symptoms of [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]], certain heart conditions, [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], and certain chronic kidney conditions, as another free prescription. Customers can get a 90-day supply of this prescription for free at any Publix Pharmacy, up to a maximum of 180 tablets. Lisinopril-HCTZ combination products are excluded. In May 2014, Publix began offering [[Amlodipine]], a [[calcium channel blocker]] used to treat [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]] and chest pain ([[Angina pectoris|angina]]) as a free medication. Customers can get a 90-day supply of this medication (up to 180 2.5-mg or 5-mg tablets, or 90 10-mg tablets) free of charge. [[Montelukast]], a medicine used for the treatment of [[Allergy|allergies]] and [[asthma]], was added to the free medication program in February 2017. 90-day supplies of 4- or 5-mg chewable tablets for children, or 10-mg oral [[Tablet (pharmacy)|tablets]] for adults, are available with a doctor's [[Prescription drug|prescription]].{{Cite news|url=http://finance.yahoo.com/news/publix-pharmacy-provides-free-montelukast-153000776.html|title=Publix Pharmacy Provides Free Montelukast|last=|first=|date=February 23, 2017|newspaper=|access-date=February 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224054240/http://finance.yahoo.com/news/publix-pharmacy-provides-free-montelukast-153000776.html|archive-date=February 24, 2017|dead-url=yes|work=|language=en-US|via=}} ====The Little Clinic==== In early 2006, Publix and The Little Clinic signed an exclusive agreement to open medical clinics within Publix stores. The first clinics were opened in the [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta]], [[Miami metropolitan area|Miami]], [[Greater Orlando|Orlando]], and [[Tampa Bay Area|Tampa]] markets in the first half of 2006. The Little Clinic health-care centers were staffed by nurse practitioners who can write prescriptions, provide diagnosis and treatment of common ailments and minor injuries, and offer wellness care like physicals, screenings, and vaccinations.{{cite news| title=Publix and The Little Clinic to Open Walk-in Medical Clinics| date=February 6, 2006| work=Business Library| publisher=Findarticles.com}} Effective May 9, 2011, Publix closed the Little Clinics in its stores in order to focus on its core pharmacy and grocery business.{{cite news| title=Publix Closes Little Clinics| author=Sandra Pedicini| date=May 17, 2011| work=Orlando Sentinel| publisher=OrlandoSentinel.com}} ==== BayCare telehealth sites ==== Publix and BayCare Health System announced a collaboration to provide [[telehealth]] and [[telemedicine]] services at specialized [[Pharmacy|pharmacies]] in four [[Tampa Bay Area|Tampa Bay]]-area counties in March 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/news/2017/03/17/publix-partners-with-baycare-on-in-store.html|title=Publix partners with BayCare on in-store telehealth sites in the Bay area|last=Manning|first=Margie|date=March 17, 2017|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=March 30, 2017|registration=yes}} Pharmacies participating in the program have private rooms for [[patient]]s to speak with a [[Board certification|board-certified]] [[physician]] in BayCare's network via [[Teleconference|teleconferencing]], plus diagnostic tools that can be used by the patient, with or without assistance from pharmacy staff.{{Cite news|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-and-baycare-health-system-announce-exclusive-four-county-colllaboration|title=Publix and BayCare Health System Announce Exclusive Four-County Collaboration {{!}} Newsroom|last=|first=|date=March 17, 2017|work=Publix Super Markets|access-date=March 30, 2017|language=en-us}} Doctors will be able to perform [[Physical examination|basic exams]] and write [[Prescription drug|prescriptions]] for minor illnesses and conditions for patients.{{Cite news|url=http://wusfnews.wusf.usf.edu/post/baycare-publix-team-create-telehealth-facilities#stream/0|title=BayCare, Publix Team Up To Create Telehealth Facilities|last=Miller|first=Daylina|access-date=March 30, 2017|language=en}} === Online shopping and delivery services === [[File:PublixDirectLogo.png|thumb|Logo of the defunct PublixDirect online shopping and delivery service]] ==== Publix Curbside ==== After PublixDirect, Publix made a second attempt in 2010 at [[e-commerce]] with the introduction of Publix Curbside. Customers had the ability to browse and purchase groceries online, then drive to a participating location where an associate will have selected their items and would bring them out to the buyer's vehicle.{{Cite web|url=https://www.internetretailer.com/2010/08/16/publix-launches-its-second-e-commerce-attempt|title=Publix launches its second e-commerce attempt|last=Enright|first=Allison|date=August 10, 2010|website=Internet Retailer Magazine|publisher=|access-date=July 8, 2016}} Announced as a [[Pilot experiment|pilot program]] with locations in the [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta area]] and [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], the program was ended in January 2012 after its performance reportedly did not meet expectations.{{Cite web|url=https://www.internetretailer.com/2012/01/06/publix-will-exit-e-commerce-second-time|title=Publix will exit e-commerce for a second time|last=Enright|first=Allison|date=January 6, 2012|website=Internet Retailer Magazine|publisher=|access-date=July 8, 2016}} The company later resurrected its curbside concept, this time using its delivery partner, [[Instacart]], to manage the online ordering portion of the service. Currently in a [[Pilot experiment|trial]] stage, the second iteration of Publix Curbside began with two pilot locations in the [[Tampa Bay Area|greater Tampa area]] in September 2017, and is expected to expand to the [[Atlanta metropolitan area|greater Atlanta area]] by the end of the year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170927006336/en/Publix-Tests-Curbside-Grocery-Pickup|title=Publix Tests Curbside Grocery Pickup|last=|first=|date=September 27, 2017|website=BusinessWire|language=en|access-date=September 27, 2017}} ==== Instacart ==== In July 2016, Publix announced another [[Pilot experiment|pilot program]] with [[Instacart]] to offer online shopping and delivery services in the [[Miami metropolitan area|greater Miami]] area. Customers in 37 [[ZIP code]]s from [[Hallandale Beach, Florida|Hallandale Beach]] to [[South Miami, Florida|South Miami]] are able to participate in the program. Not all products available at stores, such as [[tobacco]], [[gift card]]s, [[Prescription drug|prescriptions]], and age-restricted items, are able to be delivered by the service.{{Cite web|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-and-instacart-announce-delivery-service-in-greater-miami-area|title=Publix and Instacart Announce Instacart Grocery Delivery Service Available in Greater Miami Area|last=|first=|date=|website=Publix Newsroom|publisher=|access-date=July 6, 2016}} Beer and wine can be delivered in Florida and North Carolina only.{{fact|date=May 2018}} As of February 2017, Instacart deliveries from Publix are available in the metro areas of [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta]], [[Charlotte metropolitan area|Charlotte]], [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]],{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Publix/status/768779970780893185|title=Publix on Twitter|access-date=August 26, 2016}} [[Miami metropolitan area|Miami]], [[Greater Orlando|Orlando]], [[Raleigh metropolitan area|Raleigh]], [[Tampa metropolitan area|Tampa]], [[Jacksonville metropolitan area|Jacksonville]], and [[Nashville metropolitan area|Nashville]], as determined by ZIP code.{{Cite web|url=https://www.instacart.com/publix|title=Publix Grocery Delivery - Instacart|website=Instacart|language=en-US|access-date=February 13, 2017}} Later in 2017, Publix announced its intent to expand its delivery program, and expects to have the service available from more than 90 percent of stores by the end of the year. === Food World === In response to other grocery stores' aggressive discounting across the Florida market, Publix opened its first Food World store in September 1970 in [[Orlando, Florida]].{{cite web| title=Publix - Shopping Pleasure in the 70's| url=http://pleasantfamilyshopping.blogspot.com/2009/09/publix-shopping-pleasure-in-seventies.html| date=September 10, 2009| author=Dave Aldrich |work=Pleasant Family Shopping |accessdate=November 8, 2015}} The store marked the first under the Food World banner for Publix and would become the first of 22 more of the type.{{cite news|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/publix-super-markets-inc-history/|title=Publix Super Markets Inc. History|date=200|work=International Directory of Company Histories, Vol. 31.|publisher=St. James Press|accessdate=November 8, 2015}} In November 1977, in [[Lakeland, Florida]], Publix opened the Lake Miriam Food World, which, at 57,000 sq. ft., was its largest store in the company and also the largest store in the [[Southeastern United States|southeast]]. The store was the company's first to feature [[Barcode reader|barcode scanners]]. The brand was retired in 1985 because the stores were unable to turn a profit for Publix or give workers a percentage of their store's profits. === Publix PIX === Starting in 2001, Publix operated 14 PIX (stylized in all-capitals) [[Filling station|gasoline]]-[[convenience store]]s in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and [[Tennessee]]. Locations were limited during the trial period of the concept. In 2014, all Florida and Georgia locations were sold to [[Circle K]], the sole Tennessee location was sold to another entity, and the concept was discontinued.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20131023/news/131029728?tc=ar|title=Publix Plans to Sell Its Pix Stores|last=Pera|first=Eric|date=October 23, 2013|website=TheLedger.com|access-date=July 12, 2016}} The locations were converted to other brands, as Publix retains the rights to "PIX."{{Cite web|url=http://corporate.publix.com/about-publix/newsroom/news-releases/publix-to-sell-14-pix-locations|title=Publix to Sell 14 PIX Locations|date=October 22, 2013|website=Publix.com|access-date=July 12, 2016}} === Crispers === In 2002, Publix invested in the Lakeland-based [[Chain store|restaurant chain]] [[Crispers (restaurant)|Crispers]], which concentrates on health-conscious fare. It increased its stake in 2004 before purchasing the remainder of the company in 2007. In May 2011, Publix announced it had sold the Crispers chain to Healthy Food Concepts LLC. The stores had not performed well during the downturn and in recent years Publix closed several units, leaving the chain with 36 stores when the sale was announced.{{cite news| title=Publix to sell Crispers| url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20110510/NEWS/110519969/1410?Title=Publix-to-Sell-Crispers| author=Kyle Kennedy| date=May 10, 2011| work=The Ledger|location=Lakeland, Florida| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} === Publix Liquors === Publix tested the market response to liquor stores in the late 1980s, but closed its test sites in 1989. It re-entered the liquor sales market again in 2003 and has met with success since.{{cite news|url=http://www.theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20030606/NEWS/306060343/1001/BUSINESS|title=Publix Opens Liquor Stores, Promotes 'Unique Service' in Ads|date=June 6, 2003|work=The Ledger|location=Lakeland, Florida|author=Mary Toothman|accessdate=October 19, 2011}} The liquor store is in an area accessed via a separate entrance as required by local laws, modeled after many other grocery chains. === DVD rental kiosks === In September 2010, Publix reported it started adding [[Blockbuster Inc.|Blockbuster]] DVD rental kiosks to its stores, with the movie rentals starting at $1 per day. In 2010, Publix completed its rollout of Blockbuster Express kiosks to its stores.{{cite news|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20090925/NEWS/909255049/1178?Title=DVD-Kiosks-Are-Popping-Up-All-Over-Polk-County|title=DVD Kiosks Are Popping Up All Over Polk County|date=September 25, 2009|work=The Ledger|author=Kyle Kennedy|location=Lakeland, Florida|accessdate=October 19, 2011}} In 2012, [[NCR Corporation|NCR]] sold its entertainment division, which includes the Blockbuster Express kiosks, to [[CoinStar|Coinstar]], the owner of the [[Redbox]] DVD rental kiosks.{{cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/02/06/redbox-snatches-up-ncrs-entertainment-division-future-of-block/|title=Redbox snatches up NCR's entertainment division|date=February 6, 2012|work=CNET|publisher=CNET News|author=Greg Sandoval|accessdate=November 30, 2012}} Blockbuster Express machines were replaced with Redbox machines in most stores by the end of 2012. === Starbucks === In December 2016, Publix opened its first in-store [[Starbucks]] location in the Orlando area, with five more opening throughout 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/consumer/os-cfb-restaurant-retail-1226-20161222-story.html|title=Publix experimenting with Starbucks cafes|last=Arnold|first=Kyle|newspaper=OrlandoSentinel.com|language=en-US|access-date=January 19, 2017}}{{Cite (Video)|last=Gurbal Kritzer|first=Ashley|date=January 18, 2017|website=www.bizjournals.com|publisher=Jacksonville Business Journal|access-date=January 19, 2017}} === ''Presto!'' === {{Infobox There are over 1,100 ''Presto!'' ATMs in [[Florida]], [[Alabama]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[North Carolina]], [[South Carolina]], and [[Tennessee]], all located at Publix retail stores. This network includes [[point of sale]] (POS) capabilities, meaning that [[Debit card|debit]], [[Credit card|credit]], [[electronic benefit transfer]] (EBT) cash, or EBT [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program|food stamp]] cards can be used to make purchases at any Publix store. == Working environment == [[File:Publix Corporate Headquarters with clouds, Lakeland Florida.JPG|thumb|Corporate headquarters building]] The company, founded in 1930, has never had a [[layoff]].{{Cite web|url=http://archive.fortune.com/galleries/2009/fortune/0901/gallery.no_layoffs.fortune/9.html|title=No layoffs -- ever!|website=Fortune|access-date=July 8, 2016}} In 1995 Publix was sued "for sex discrimination in job assignments, promotions and allocation of hours" and settled for $81.5 million in 1997.{{Cite web|title = Publix Markets Settles Bias Suit for $81.5 Million|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1997-01-25/business/fi-22037_1_publix-markets-settles-bias-suit|website = Los Angeles Times|accessdate = May 8, 2015}} Publix had claimed that the suit was simply an effort by the [[United Food and Commercial Workers]] to unionize the company, but the judge ruled in favor of the plaintiffs and required Publix to "correct some of its statements."{{Cite web|title = Supermarket Chain To Pay $81 Million To Settle a Bias Suit|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/25/business/supermarket-chain-to-pay-81-million-to-settle-a-bias-suit.html|website = [[The New York Times]]|author=Myerson, Allen R.|date=January 25, 1997}} Publix announced that effective January 1, 2015, health coverage would be available to same-sex couples regardless of place of marriage, as long as they are legally married.{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2014/12/30/pf/publix-same-sex-benefits/index.html|title=Publix offering workers same-sex health benefits|last=Lobosco|first=Katie|date=December 30, 2014|website=[[CNN Money]]|access-date=May 13, 2016}} ==Charitable and political giving== Publix regularly conducts charity drives raising money and food for such charities as [[Special Olympics]], [[March of Dimes]], [[Children's Miracle Network]], [[United Way of America|United Way]], as well as various local food banks and soup kitchens such as Our Father's House Soup Kitchen{{cite web| title=Corporate Campaigns| url=http://www.publix.com/about/company-overview/community-involvement/Corporate-Campaigns.do| publisher=Publix| accessdate=October 19, 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407040432/http://www.publix.com/about/company-overview/community-involvement/Corporate-Campaigns.do| archivedate=April 7, 2012| df=}} and [[Second Harvest North Florida]]. On May 25, 2018, student activists and survivors of the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]], including [[David Hogg (activist)|David Hogg]], planned a boycott of Publix, which would have included "die-in" protests at several Publix supermarkets, because of the $670,000 that the company made to [[Adam Putnam]], a Republican candidate for Florida governor and self-described "proud [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] sell-out"{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/business/wp/2018/05/25/publix-suspends-contributions-to-adam-putnam-amid-david-hoggs-anti-nra-protests/?noredirect=on|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 25, 2018|author=Eltagouri, Marwa|title=Publix halts donations to self-described ‘NRA sellout’ amid boycott, ‘die-in’ protests by David Hogg}} who opposed new state gun restrictions created in response to the school shooting.{{cite news| url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/politics/fl-reg-adam-putnam-governor-forum-club-20180427-story.html|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|title=Adam Putnam champions 2nd Amendment, explains calling himself proud NRA sellout|date=April 30, 2018|author=Man, Anthony]}} Moments before the protests began, the company announced that it would suspend corporate-funded political contributions and reevaluate their political funding practices. Despite the company's announcement, David Hogg led a die-in on May 25, 2018 at a Publix supermarket with parents and students from [[Stoneman Douglas High School]] for 720 seconds, the approximate number of school shootings in recent history.{{cite news| url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/local/broward/parkland/florida-school-shooting/fl-florida-school-shooting-publix-die-in-20180524-story.html|title=Publix halts campaign donations minutes before students stage 'die-in' protests|newspaper=Sun-Sentinel|date=May 25, 2018|author=Geggis, Anne Geggis; Barszewski, Larry; Shatzman, Marci}} Six days after halting political contributions, the [[Florida Retail Federation]], a trade group heavily funded (>80% in 2017) by Publix, donated an additional $100,000 to Putnam's Florida Grown political action committee.{{cite news|author=Wolf, Colin|url=https://www.orlandoweekly.com/Blogs/archives/2018/06/08/a-lobbying-group-funded-almost-entirely-by-publix-just-gave-100k-to-proud-nra-sellout-adam-putnam|title=A lobbying group funded almost entirely by Publix just gave 100k to proud NRA sellout Adam Putnam|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date= June 8, 2018}} ==Stock== [[File:Publix Corporate Headquarters Main Entrance Sign, Lakeland Florida.jpg|thumb|Main entrance to the corporate headquarters]] Publix stock is private and restricted: it can only be purchased by current employees or board members, and cannot be sold to anyone without first being offered back to Publix for repurchase.{{cite web| title=Stockholder Services| url=http://www.publixstockholder.com/servlet/ProxyServlet?path=/stockholder/Services.do| publisher=Publix| accessdate=October 19, 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001505/http://www.publixstockholder.com/servlet/ProxyServlet?path=%2Fstockholder%2FServices.do| archivedate=March 4, 2016| df=}} Stock was made available to associates in 1959, originally priced at $10.00 per share.{{cite web|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/LK/20051111/News/608143977/LL/|newspaper=The Ledger|author=Toothman, Marty|date=November 11, 2005|accessdate=June 2, 2018|title=Board: Split Publix Stock}} Employees can acquire stock through three programs: an [[Employee stock ownership plan|ESOP]] "PROFIT"{{Cite news|url=http://www.gbhcpas.com/blog/3-lessons-weve-learned-from-publix-for-a-successful-esop|title=3 Lessons We've Learned From Publix for a Successful ESOP|last=Canon|first=Gary|date=June 19, 2017|work=GBH CPAs blog|access-date=November 28, 2017|language=en}} plan, [[401(k)]] "SMART" (Saving Makes A Richer Tomorrow) plan, and an [[employee stock purchase plan]]. As of August 1, 2018, Publix stock is valued at $42.55 per share.{{Cite news|url=http://publixstockholder.com/|title=Publix Investor Relations {{!}} Shareholder and Stock Information|work=Publix Super Markets|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-us}} Publix stock is quoted on the US [[Over the counter (finance)|OTC]] market under the code PUSH.{{cite web|title=Bloomberg |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/PUSH:US |accessdate=December 29, 2014}} It is listed on the 2016 [[Fortune 500]] list at #87.{{cite web|work=Fortune|title=87 Publix Super Markets |url=http://beta.fortune.com/fortune500/publix-super-markets-87|accessdate=December 17, 2016}} == Locations == [[File:Publix.JPG|thumb|Publix in Jacksonville]] {|class="wikitable" |- ! Total | '''1,242''' |} ===Distribution centers=== Distribution centers are located in: * Alabama ** [[McCalla, Alabama|McCalla]] – non-perishables * Florida ** [[Boynton Beach, Florida|Boynton Beach]] – grocery ** [[Deerfield Beach, Florida|Deerfield Beach]] – perishables ** [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] – dairy, frozen food, grocery, meat, produce ** [[Lakeland, Florida|Lakeland]] – frozen food, grocery ** [[Miami, Florida|Miami]] – grocery ** [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] – frozen food, meat, produce ** [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]] – grocery * Georgia ** [[Dacula, Georgia|Dacula]] – dairy, frozen food, grocery, meat, produce ===Manufacturing facilities=== Manufacturing facilities are located in: * Florida ** [[Deerfield Beach, FL|Deerfield Beach]] – dairy, fresh foods ** [[Jacksonville, FL|Jacksonville]] – fresh foods ** [[Lakeland, FL|Lakeland]] – bakery, dairy, deli, fresh foods, printing services * Georgia ** [[Dacula, Georgia|Dacula]] – dairy, fresh foods ** [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] – bakery ===Support offices=== * Florida ** [[Lakeland, FL|Lakeland]] – [[Office|corporate offices]], [[Data center|IT data center]], [[Corporate travel management|flight center]], [[Technical support|programming and IT support]], [[Call centre|call center]] and [[Customer service|customer care]] ** [[Jacksonville, FL|Jacksonville]] – offices ** [[Miami, FL|Miami]] – offices * Georgia ** [[Marietta, Georgia|Marietta]] – offices ** [[Alpharetta, Georgia|Alpharetta]] – IT data center * North Carolina ** [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]] – offices == Legal disputes == In 2003, Publix supported a successful bill that prevents owners from suing if their land is polluted by dry cleaning chemicals dumped on an adjacent property, if the adjacent property owners are on a state clean-up list. Publix lost a 2001 lawsuit filed by an owner whose property had been contaminated in this manner.{{cite news| title=Bill: No suing over cleaning chemical| url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/03/10/State/Bill__No_suing_over_c.shtml| work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]| author=Julie Hauserman| date=March 10, 2003| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} On October 4, 2005, Publix sued [[VISA (credit card)|Visa]] and [[MasterCard]], citing unfair business practices over their unannounced and non-negotiable increases in [[merchant account]] fees.{{cite news| title=Publix sues Visa, MasterCard Over Intercharge Rates| author=Christine Van Dusen| url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/261239/publix_sues_visa_mastercard_over_interchange_rates| date=October 5, 2005| work=Atlanta Journal-Constitution| publisher=redOrbit.com| accessdate=October 19, 2011}} [[Wal-Mart]] won a similar lawsuit against Visa in 2004. In 2014, Publix was fined by the Board of Human Rights of [[Broward County, Florida]] for discrimination involved in the termination of an [[LGBT]] employee.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/riptide/2014/01/publix_ordered_to_pay_cake_dec.php|title=Publix Ordered to Pay Cake Decorator $100,000 for Firing Him Because He's Gay|publisher=Miami New Times|author=Michael E. Miller|date=January 8, 2014|accessdate=February 8, 2014}} Upon appeal, the 17th Circuit Court found that the decision by the Board of Human Rights of Broward County was "not supported by competent, substantial evidence" and quashed the order.{{cite web|title=Case Detail CACE13005809: Publix Super Markets Inc. Hynix is the world's second-largest memory chipmaker (after [[Samsung Electronics]]){{cite news| url= http://bigstory.ap.org/article/sk-hynix-sinks-loss-oversupply-weak-demand | title= SK Hynix sinks to loss on oversupply, weak demand | first= Youkyung| last= Lee | date= 26 July 2012| location= Seoul, South Korea |accessdate= 11 June 2013}} and the world's fifth-largest semiconductor company.{{cite news| url= http://www.icinsights.com/news/bulletins/Six-Top-20-1Q15-Semiconductor-Suppliers-Show-20-Growth-/ | title= Top 20 1Q15 Semiconductor Suppliers | publisher= Research and Markets| location= Dublin | accessdate= 11 June 2013}} Founded as '''Hyundai Electronic Industrial Co., Ltd.''' in 1983{{cite web | url= http://m.hynix.com/mobile_gl/about_ir_5.html | publisher= SK Hynix | title= Investor Relations: FAQ | accessdate= 11 June 2013 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121230045106/http://m.hynix.com/mobile_gl/about_ir_5.html | archivedate= 30 December 2012 | df= }} and known as '''Hyundai Electronics''', the company has manufacturing sites in Korea, the [[United States]], [[China]][http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/techscience/2010/06/17/0601000000AEN20100617004651320.HTML Hynix completes new chip plant in China], Yonhap News Agency, 17 June 2010. and [[Taiwan]]. In 2012, when [[SK Telecom]] became its major shareholder, Hynix merged to [[SK Group]] (the third largest conglomerate in South Korea). The company's shares are traded on the [[Korea Stock Exchange]], and the Global Depository shares are listed on the [[Luxembourg Stock Exchange]]. Hynix memory is used by [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] in some of their [[iMac]], [[MacBook]] and [[MacBook Pro]] computers. Apple's [[Apple A9|A9]] chipset is onboard together with an SK Hynix RAM module believed to be "likely the same 2 GB LPDDR4 mobile DRAM found in the [[iPhone 6S|iPhone 6s]]".By Paul Briden, Know Your Mobile. “[http://www.knowyourmobile.com/mobile-phones/apple-iphone-7c/23386/iphone-5se-release-date-specs-iphone-7-ios-93 iPhone SE One Week Later: "Adoption Has Been Low"].” April 8, 2016. April 8, 2016. Hynix memory is also used by [[Asus]] in their [[Google]]-branded Nexus 7 tablet (both [[Nexus 7 (2012)|2012]] and [[Nexus 7 (2013)|2013]] models, respectively), an OEM provider for [[IBM System x]] servers, and is used in [[Desktop computer|desktop PCs]] and [[laptop]]s as well as the [[Asus Eee PC]]. [[Dell]], [[HP Inc.]] and [[Hewlett Packard Enterprise]] (formerly [[Hewlett-Packard]]) have also used Hynix memory as OEM equipment. Other products that use Hynix memory include [[DVD player]]s, [[cellular phone]]s, [[set-top box]]es, [[personal digital assistant]]s, networking equipment, and [[hard disk drive]]s.{{cite news| url= http://www.researchandmarkets.com/research/nbf3kk/analysis_of_sk | title= Analysis of SK Hynix | publisher= Research and Markets| location= Dublin | accessdate= 11 June 2013}} ==History== * '''1983''' Founded as Hyundai Electronics Industries Co., Ltd. * '''1985''' Started mass production of 256K DRAM * '''1986''' The Hyundai-manufactured Blue Chip PC was sold in discount and toy stores throughout the US. [[File:Solander Box.jpg|thumb|right|A Solander Box]] A '''Solander box''' ("S" may also be in lowercase), or '''clamshell case''' (mainly in [[American English]]), is a book-form case used for storing manuscripts, maps, prints, documents, old and precious books, etc. It is commonly used in [[archive]]s, [[print room]]s and [[library|libraries]]. It is named after the Swedish [[botanist]] [[Daniel Solander]] (1733–1782),<ref>{{cite book|author-link=Edward Duyker|first=Edward|last=Duyker|date=1998|title=Nature's Argonaut: Daniel Solander 1733-1782: Naturalist and Voyager with Cook and Banks|publisher=Melbourne University Press|ISBN=0-522-84753-6}}</ref> who is credited with its construction while working at the [[British Museum]], where he catalogued the natural history collection between 1763 and 1782.
The case is usually constructed of [[hardcover]] or wood, and has a hinged lid connected to its base. Both lid and bottom sections of the box have three fixed side sections or "lips"; the lid is slightly larger so that the side pieces "nest" when the case is closed. The fourth "spine" side has flexible joints where it joins the main top and bottom pieces and so goes flat onto the surface where the box is opened. The front-edge of the case often contains a clasp for closure. The exterior is covered with heavy paper, fabric or leather, and its interior may be lined with padded paper or [[felt]], especially if made for a book. All materials should be acid-free for conservation. The depth of the box is normally about five inches, if it is not made for a specific object, and various standard sizes are made, with traditional names including "royal", "imperial", "elephant" and others. Ones for very old books will typically be custom made to an exact size. The boxes are stored flat, and are strong enough to be kept in small stacks.
A simplified and undecorated form of Solander box termed a "phase box" is used for temporary storage of books during [[conservation-restoration|conservation]] work.<ref>{{cite web|title=Easy do-it-yourself storage enclosures for books |url=http://archive.amol.org.au/recollections/1/2/13.htm |publisher=reCollections: Caring for Collections Across Australia] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731054232/http://archive.amol.org.au/recollections/1/2/13.htm |archivedate=July 31, 2009 }}</ref> These are constructed from plain mounting board. Although undecorated, the materials should still be of archival grade.
